What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List: I was able to learn the first half of the introductory sequence of physics.
I learned quantitative reasoning skills and how to approach basic physics problems. In particular, we learned about kinematics, dynamics, rotation, gravitation and simple harmonic motion.
The fundamentals of calculus based physics, conceptually and applying that knowledge to potential real-world scenarios

I learnt about how to think in physics terms. I really appreciated trying to understand the material and the first 11 chapters of the textbook. I was used to plugging in numbers and trying to make them work in equations, but I am now starting to appreciate using symbols (like G, m, a, etc) to figure out what to do, then plug in numbers at the end and I think that might be a helpful approach in future.
I strengthened my ability to tackle problems quantitatively and overcame my fear of physics.
I developed some of the elementary skills of calculus-based physics.

The course was well taught, the professor would go through a lot of practice problems which was helpful. I do with the professor would sometime give students the chance to solve the problems he would go over before showing how to do it on the board because I feel like this would be more helpful.
Good teaching
This was a really decent introductory physics class. I think the sections could be improved, especially in the first part of the course. However, it was useful to go through problems.

Strengths: The real life application was apparent.

Weaknesses: I wish the content was more involved and utilized more of what we learned in regards to calculus. I learned the concepts of calculus based physics but there was so little calculus that it didn't even feel like it was calculus based.
I think the course is good as it is. I think it was good to have P-sets due every week and think the midterms were well spaced-out.

Strengths are large amount of problems used to show learned concepts, and lots of time given to review harder ideas, as well as easily-understood lectures. Weaknesses are in that problems are described and solved without a lot of student input. An improvement could be that discussions have problems solved by the students which are then talked about.

This course does a superb job introducing students to all the course material taught during the academic calendar year, but, by virtue of being a summer course, prevents students from taking time to appreciate the nuances of some concepts.

Weaknesses--no acknowledgment of varying levels of physics experience before coming in. There were people in the class that have taken physics before, which I feel detracted from the learning experience of others who haven't, as the professor sometimes assumed we knew something because others were knowledgable about it.
It was very well organized in every way.
Yes!
Yes
I would recommend that other pre-med students do physics over the summer because it is well-taught and less stressful than during the school year.

I wouldn't recommend this course. Mehdi was a great professor and he taught the content very well; however, the content wasn't the most interesting in the world and because of that I can't recommend this course

I took this class as a pre-med requirement. I think it is pretty good in terms of thinking with a physics mindset and can help aid your understanding of biological and chemical processes. Thus said, I'd say do it if you need to or just want to be exposed to another science-y way of thinking. For me, it was helpful to read before the class, especially since the summer course is relatively fast-paced.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who is interested in applying mathematics.
If you need it, I recommend it during the summer because during the year it could be pretty exhausting.
Yes, a fun course to take--especially over the summer!
